Thus, the scholars of the Warring States—like **Lǔ Zhònglián** and **Yú Qīng**—were they not also men of the Dao? **Yú Qīng**, unable to endure the suffering of **Wèi** and **Qí**, secretly left for **Zhào**, only to be imprisoned in **Liáng** and stripped of his office, reduced to writing in despair. **Qúo Tōng**, though his counsel went unheeded, feigned madness as a shaman, fled to **Héngkè** and **Cānshān**, composing his own theories—was he not also one who attained the Dao? He refused to serve in office, upholding lofty principles, debating the harm of **Wèi** and **Qín**’s imperial schemes, dismissing the governor of **Liáochéng**. When offered gold, he declined, saying:

*"What the world values in its worthies is their ability to dispel calamities, resolve difficulties, and settle strife without seeking personal gain. If they do seek gain, then they are no better than merchants—and I cannot bear to act thus."*

When pressed for office, he said: *"I would rather endure poverty and obscurity, defying the world with my will, than bow to wealth and honor, bending to others."*

Ah! Only one such as **Lǔ Zhònglián** could truly be called transcendent. **Ānqī Shēng**’s name appears in histories and scattered records, yet his deeds seem too fantastic to be true. If he were like **Lǔ Zhònglián**, striking his palm to summon a rainbow, or like the legendary **Zhāng Liú** and **Gāng Dé**, who bore mountains and wielded cauldrons—both accounts are clearly erroneous. Yet his lingering spirit remains. Thus, it is said that those who govern the world may also transcend it, ascending like dragons.

**Zōngyǔ**’s elucidation of the *Three Books of Gold Elixir* surpasses the mundane, fixed in eternal truths beyond the world, unlike the *Eight Chapters of the Marvelous*, which merely mocks power and political maneuvering. His work is the true successor to **Lǔ Zhònglián** and **Ānqī Shēng**. As for **Yú Qīng** and **Qúo Tōng**, they were merely strategists—how could they compare?

**Recorded on the fifth day after the Winter Solstice, in the year *Bǎobǎo Bǐngxū* (1256), by Qīngyuān Zhīyún Shānrén.**

**Yúnfēng’s Continuation:**
*"Summer clouds bear strange peaks"*—a phrase the Jin poets delighted in. I, in my fleeting guise, adopt this fleeting name, truly adding legs to a painted snake and a neck to a decoy bird. Perhaps some will imitate the *Grand Historian*’s fondness for the strange, or steal the poet’s clever phrases, to display themselves. Alas! Summer is one of the four seasons, and clouds are but one breath of *qi*—where do these peaks arise? What is this strangeness? They rise without intent, follow the dragon without trace, bring rain or drought, stir wind or storm—thousands of wonders, transformations beyond measure. Yet these are not my intent.

Is it not that the **Heavenly One** clears with purity, the **Earthly One** settles with tranquility, the **Jade Emperor** holds the balance, and the **Flame Sovereign** blazes above? The south wind blows gently, the sun shines like steam, the **Fire Umbrella** burns fiercely, melting gold and stone. These are not mere clouds, nor mere peaks—they are the **Celestial Worthy’s** gathered essence, the **Divine Spirit’s** concentrated will.

The **Bright Hall** opens vast, the **Purple Court** stands serene. The **Venerable Lord Dīng** refines the golden essence. **Kūnlún** thrives in splendor, the **Jade Well** shines deep. The **Primordial Furnace** glows warm, the **Crescent Crucible** flickers bright. The **Cyclical Winds** blend, thunder crashes in harmony. Above, it pierces the **Celestial Apertures**; below, it descends into the **Mysterious Depths**. The **Four Celestial Guardians** and **Six Divine Warriors** attend. The **Circumferential Heaven’s** revolutions are complete—nine transformations, ascension achieved.

How then is **Yúnfēng** merely a strange name? Profound is the Great Dao—Heaven and Earth’s **virtue/power** unite. Before **Yuánshǐ**’s breath divided into yin and yang, what was heavy and what was light? When **Hóngméng** was cleaved, Heaven, Earth, and Man were born—Man, the most refined. The revolutions of transformation endure through the eons. The **Black Tortoise** and **White Tiger** symbols stand clear, the **Lunar and Solar cycles** align. Yet in the ninth month, when the **Summer Solstice** lingers, the clouds alone bear peaks.

When the **Regal Stem** reaches the third **Five-Day Period** of summer, fire must retreat westward. The **Golden Elixir’s** mysteries lie in fire’s essence. The clouds rise with fiery *qi*, the peaks manifest divine form. The **Water Phase’s** marrow is refined, the **Heavenly Stem’s** and **Earthly Branch’s** essences are seized. Yin’s malevolence is dispelled, pure yang is perfected. Heaven and Earth complete their work—death yields to rebirth.

**Yúnfēng’s** strangeness is beyond comprehension. Who but the **True One** could unveil its secrets? Some may stand speechless, exclaiming only *"How strange!"*—yet they fail to see that Confucianism is too rigid, Buddhism too stagnant, while the Dao equals the **Great Void**, yet holds its roots. Heaven and Earth vast, the Dao gives birth; myriad things scatter, the Dao sustains; the sun and moon traverse east and west, the Dao governs. These clouds as peaks—it is the Dao that manifests them.

I have seen the **One True Reality**, unmoving yet commanding all spirits. The two breaths interweave, generating all things. Who knows—are these clouds the peaks, or the peaks the clouds?

Thus, the **Seven Returns and Nine Reversions**, the **Eight Reunions and Six Residences**, the **Mystic Pearl’s** formation, and the **True Person’s** emergence—all are **Yúnfēng**. Profound! Mysterious! How could mere poetic phrases capture its essence?

**Recorded by Dǒuchéng Xià Yuándǐng.**

**Yúnfēng’s Self-Introduction:**
Disturbance is the root of worldly affairs; stillness and clarity are the **Pharmacopoeia Mirror’s** essence—this is **Cuī Gōng**’s profound teaching. Is it not that man’s life is but a temporary assembly of the Four Great Elements? Tears, saliva, semen, blood, and bodily fluids—all are yin’s impurities. Lust, greed, anger, and delusion—all are worldly entanglements. Only the **Pharmacopoeia’s** stillness and clarity can subdue them.

What is this *"medicine"*? It is **cinnabar** and **wood essence**, refined with gold—thus they become one.

chunks.original_text: 窃闻先训九万之曾王父殿撰公讳子献，宣和间尝偕吕元直丞相、霍安国尚书三人衔命漕燕。 是时降虏郭药师、刘舜仁、张令徽辈包藏不测，三使者同衔上章乞弃燕，忤大阖谭稹，各落职不得去。 黠虏愈张，三使者极力堤虞，每夕不寐，曾王父因是得以神守气之术，其后寿八十九，无疾而终。 前一日，尚呼灯作小楷以复李伯纪丞相，中间颜夷仲门下尝间以书，曾王父为言人知气为体之充，而不知以神御气，则神与气相离而不相守，非养生之善者。 夫以神御气者，在於正心诚意，宴坐而数出入息。 盖息者，气也。 数之者，神也。 气犹马，神犹驭，以神驭气之出入而不相离，则可以长生矣。 《庄子》曰：真人之息以踵，众人之息以喉。 夫息不於喉而在丹田气海中，能不以思欲干其神，不以蹶趋动其气，绵绵然数之，以至于不可胜数，自浅而之深，自粗而之微，自有而入於无，则和气充塞于顶踵之间，不知气之为神，神之为气，其妙有不容言者矣。 是几於坐忘者欤？ 至其助以经伸按摩之术，自亦无害，在乎不倦而已。 晦翁先生尝曰：此胎息法也，然亦《参同契》之绪余耳。 又孰若云峰金丹三书超然自应，显化通神，灵明妙用者哉？ 虽然，云峰发身於童子，而得道於衡山，又十余年颉颃兵间，其与邺侯之事异世同辙。 今圣天子寤寐不凡之士，共起治功，云峰其以邺侯之心为心，为国家了中原，而后访子房未迟也。 宝庆丁亥武夷山人序。

The **Dao** of longevity was whispered to me by my ancestor, the **Zēng** family’s **once-great-grandfather**, **Dànshèng Gōng**—whose surname was **Zēng**—who, during the **Xuānhé** era, once accompanied **Lǚ Yuánzhí**, the Chancellor, and **Huò Ānguó**, the Grand Secretary, as the three bore imperial commission to transport grain to **Yàn**. At that time, the rebellious **Guò Yàoshī**, **Liú Shùnrén**, and **Zhāng Lìnghuī** harbored treachery within their ranks. The three envoys, in unison, submitted a memorial requesting abandonment of **Yàn**, defying the will of the **Dàtā** (i.e., the court), and were thus demoted, barred from departure. The cunning barbarians grew ever more bold, and the three envoys exerted themselves to the utmost, guarding against peril night and day without rest. It was then that **Zēng Dànshèng Gōng** mastered the **shénshǒu-qì** (spirit-guarding-qi) technique, and afterward lived to eighty-nine, dying without illness.

The day before his passing, he still called for a lamp to write in small script, replying to **Lǐ Bójì**, the Chancellor. Among his words, **Yán Yízhòng**’s disciple had once inquired about the **Dao**, and **Zēng Dànshèng Gōng** spoke: *"Men know that qi is the substance, yet they do not know that one must govern qi with shén (spirit). If shén and qi separate and do not uphold each other, this is not the refined practice of nurturing life."*

Now, to govern qi with shén lies in **zhèngxīn-chéngyì** (rectifying the heart, sincerity of intent), seated in repose while counting the breaths in and out. For breath is qi, and counting is shén. Qi is like a horse, shén like its driver—when shén guides the ebb and flow of qi without separation, then longevity is attainable.

The *Zhuāngzi* says: *"The True Person’s breath originates at the heels; the common man’s at the throat."* If breath does not lodge in the throat but instead dwells in the **Dāntián-Qìhǎi** (elixir field-sea of qi), and one neither disturbs shén with thoughts or desires nor agitates qi with haste—if one gently counts it, until the count becomes boundless, from shallow to deep, from coarse to subtle, from presence to emptiness—then harmonious qi fills the space between crown and sole, and one cannot distinguish qi as shén or shén as qi. Its subtlety transcends speech.

Is this not akin to **zuòwàng** (sitting-forgetting)?

As for assisting with **jīngshēn-ànmó** (classical medical techniques of stretching, pressing, and massage), it also does no harm—so long as one does not grow weary.

**Huìyōng** once remarked: *"This is the **tāixī** (embryonic breathing) method, yet it is but the remnants of the *Cāntóng Qì* (Harmonizing the Triple One)."*

But who could compare it to **Yǒngjiā Xià Yúnfēng**’s **jīndān** (alchemical elixir) **Three Books**, transcendent and self-actualizing, manifesting wonders, communicating with the numinous, and displaying the luminous and subtle?

Yet **Yúnfēng** began his cultivation as a youth and attained the **Dao** on **Héngshān**, while later spending over a decade amid military affairs—his path, though differing in era, mirrors that of **Yèhóu** (i.e., **Xià Yúnfēng**’s earlier life). Now, under the **Sage Emperor’s** vigilant rule, extraordinary scholars arise to restore the realm. Let **Yúnfēng** take **Yèhóu’s** resolve as his own, first stabilizing the **Zhōngyuán** (Central Plains), and then seek **Zǐfáng** (Zhang Liang) shall not be too late.

**Wǔyú Shānrén** (The Man of **Wǔyú Mountain**) prefaces this in **Bǎoqìng Dīnghài**.
